intro: Drymonia solitaria, commonly known as the solitary drymonia, is a rare and distinctive plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as swamps and pine flatwoods. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, contributing to its unique botanical appearance. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is of particular interest to botanists and conservationists.
